text.0:
And that concludes some of the highlights from today's conversation w/ @Voting_Works's @benadida & former Maricopa County election official @aztammyp. 

Thank you for sharing insights on how to cover post-election audits while strengthening the public's confidence in the results!
text.1: "I really hope that local reporters think about how they can take... what's happening on the national level and bring it home. Talk about what's happening in your local office... They're still doing the same work that they're doing in other states as well." - @aztammyp
text.2: "We're going to lose some information battles. [An audit is] a subtle, slightly math-heavy thing that isn't always intuitive. It's a hard battle, but... we're talking about a level of transparency with the auditing process that is really impressive." - @benadida
text.3:
"Are we heading into a hurricane? Maybe... We're going to stick to the science, the process...

Risk-limiting audits are meant to build confidence in the accuracy of the tabulation. They're not the thing that tells you everything went well." - @benadida
text.4: @AmPress small correction: an RLA *can* grow to a full hand recount, but in most cases it succeeds much sooner, with a lot less work.
text.5:
Math is hard, but telling your audience what a "10% risk limit" is doesnt have to be:

"If the tabulator did not declare the right winner, the risk-limit is the probability that the audit will fail to catch that. You have at least a 90% chance of the audit catching it." @benadida
text.6:
A Risk-Limiting Audit: 

:white_heavy_check_mark: Does make sure a full hand count would come to the same results as the machine counting

:prohibited: Does NOT entail an actual full hand count

:white_heavy_check_mark: Does build extra confidence in the results being correct, and in the entire voting process. - @benadida
text.7:
So what does a Risk-Limiting Audit do (and not do) exactly?

:white_heavy_check_mark: It does allow ballots to be looked at by at least two political parties with the naked eye

:prohibited: It does NOT confirm a landslide or tell how big the margin was
text.8:
"Most people think 'Uh oh, an audit means something wrong.' It's exactly the opposite. 

You don't run a Risk-Limiting Audit because there was a problem, you run a Risk-Limiting Audit because you want to build confidence in the results." - @benadida
text.9:
.@benadida adds: 

"What we usually see is that the equipment functioned properly." If we do find something that needs to change, it's usually with the voting instructions or layout of ballots, not that the machine couldn't read it.
text.10:
Risk-limiting audits answer the very important question: "Was the correct winner announced?"

@benadida says: "Most of the time, elections go well. If there is an issue, it very rarely amounts to a change in the winner." https://t.co/56q6sEczTe
text.11:
And the most important questions journalists should ask while covering post-election audits:

:question_mark: Do voters know audits happen?
:question_mark: What do they think about them?
:question_mark: Does it increase their confidence in the process? https://t.co/6imkMwCDoE
text.12:
Questions journalists should ask election officials running audits:

:question_mark: What kind of audit is it? 
:question_mark: What is being audited?
:question_mark: What are the state laws?
:question_mark: How does it relate to recounts? 
:question_mark: Who pays for it?
:question_mark: Is every election audited?
:question_mark: What happens if there's a discrepancy?
text.13:
Most people want to know: what happened to the ballots, how are paper ballots handled?

@aztammyp says "An audit is only as good as the paper trail." Her advice to reporters: follow the paper. https://t.co/41WRMoxLj8
text.14:
Key point that the general population doesn't know, according to @aztammyp: 

This election had more paper ballots than ever before. Yes, there were more voters, but also there is greater use of paper ballots this year than in the last presidential election. https://t.co/nsKxbCfY2u
text.15:
3) Did the machine(s) count/work correctly? That's a Hand Count Audit. 

4) Was the correct winner called? That's a Risk-Limiting Audit. 

:up_arrow_selector: That last one is what we're going to see in Georgia.
text.16:
First off, did you know there are several types of election audits? If you've got a question, there's an audit for that. @aztammyp shares:

1) Who had access to the tabulation room? That's a security audit. 

2) Did the pollworkers make an error? That's a Reconciliation Audit.
text.17:
Post-election audits have already started, and today we're speaking with @aztammyp and @benadida to help you get the answers you need to serve your audience.

Tune into this thread to catch the highlights. A big thank you to @CraigNewmark Philanthropies for your support. https://t.co/1p1vSoLqpQ
text.19: Many thanks to all the partners involved so far, including @BorealisPhil @GetCurrentNow @McCormick_Fdn and @tribrevlab.
text.20: Sustainability can come through listening. We’re excited to announce this partnership with the Racial Equity in Journalism Fund @BorealisPhil. https://t.co/1dGhrrr5lV

user_mentions.name: Revenue Lab at The Texas Tribune
